description:
Callipepla californica brunnescens, commonly known as the Catalina Island Quail, is a subspecies of the California Quail (Callipepla californica). It is found primarily on Catalina Island, located off the coast of Southern California.

The Catalina Island Quail is a small, ground-dwelling bird that belongs to the family Odontophoridae, or New World Quails. It is distinguished by its distinctive head plume, which is a distinctive feature of the California Quail species.

The Catalina Island Quail exhibits a slightly darker overall coloration compared to the mainland subspecies of the California Quail. Its plumage is primarily shades of brown, with a grayish head and a dark brown back and wings. The birds typically measure around 10 inches in length and weigh approximately 6 ounces.

This subspecies is adapted to the unique island environment of Catalina, where it thrives in a variety of habitats, including chaparral, scrublands, and oak woodlands. It feeds on a diverse diet of seeds, insects, and other plant matter.

The Catalina Island Quail plays an important role in the island's ecosystem, serving as a prey species for predators and contributing to the dispersal of seeds through its foraging activities. Conservation efforts have been undertaken to protect this endemic subspecies and its natural habitat.
